awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Scalable and Interpretable Machine Learning: Bridging Mechanistic and Data-Driven Modeling in the Biological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid advances in information technology, an age of rich data has dawned in nearly every scientific field. Such data hold the potential to guide decision-making and accelerate understanding of complex processes such as human development and disease progression. For instance, massive databases on gene expression and other molecular processes can be used to build models to predict the drivers of a disease. Predictive models are an important step in understanding these complex systems, but equally important is the human interpretability of such models, e.g. to derive mechanistic insights into what factors drive disease onset in order to identify an appropriate course of treatment.  Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) technologies have led to a profound shift in how biological data are collected, assaying individual genomic elements that act as part of organized, stereospecific groups to drive emergent biological phenomena. These modern data call for new statistics/data science principles and scalable algorithms to advance the frontier of science.

This project focuses on developing novel scalable statistical machine learning algorithms that are predictable, stable and interpretable, and can be used to guide decision-making and discovery in biological systems. This project aims to build insights into how individual genomic elements act in concert by developing interpretable and stable supervised learning algorithms with state of the art predictive accuracy along with scalable, open source software. Many machine learning algorithms with state of the art predictive accuracies are capable of learning complicated rules that might govern complex systems but are difficult for humans to interpret. The research builds on iterative Random Forests (iRF), an algorithm recently developed by the PIs that recovers the high-order, human interpretable, Boolean type interactions that are important parts of the state-of-the-art predictive accuracy in Random Forests. The proposed work will develop and validate approaches for refining interactions recovered by iRF to produce testable hypotheses for follow-up studies, along with inference methods to assess the uncertainty associated with these hypotheses. These approaches and methods will be implemented in Apache Spark to ensure scalability to massive datasets in genomics and beyond.  Implementation of the methods for the large-scale applications will leverage cloud computing resources provided through an agreement between commercial cloud service providers and NSF for the BIGDATA solicitation.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus of this research proposal was (1) to develop scalable machine learning algorithms that predict the emergent behavior of biological and other complex systems with high accuracy and (2) to interpret the stable nonlinear interactions that drive predictive performance to help biologists and others decide for follow-up experiments.  

 

To this end, the PI developed iterative random forests (iRF) and signed iRF (siRF) to discover predictive and stable higher-order, nonlinear interactions between variables. These computationally-efficient algorithms served as effective tools to gain interpretable insights from random forests and to better understand complex biological processes. In particular, siRF demonstrated impressive performance in recovering higher-order interactions under biologically-inspired simulations and two real data case studies: predicting enhancer activity and spatial gene expression patterns. In the case of enhancer activity, siRF identified experimentally validated high-order interactions, and in the case of spatial gene expression patterns, siRF recovered an established gene network. 

 

On top of iRF and siRF, the PI further introduced the epiTree pipeline to conduct rigorous hypothesis tests and assess the significance of the candidate interactions from iRF or siRF by simulating Boolean tree-structured null (no epistasis) and alternative (epistasis) distributions on hold-out test data. This methodology was validated in a case study investigating the red-hair phenotype, where several genes are well-known to interact in a mechanism of epistasis.

 

Motivated by the effectiveness of iRF in real-world genomics and biological problems, the PI worked to improve the interpretability and predictability of tree-based methods by developing several new tree-based methodologies. For example, in order to address a known systematic bias in MDI, one of the most widely used measures of random forest (RF) feature importance, the PI proposed MDI-oob. MDI-oob is a debiased feature importance measure that evaluates MDI using out-of-bag samples and achieves state-of-the-art performance in feature selection across a broad range of simulations and a genomic ChIP case study. The PI also proposed hierarchical shrinkage (HS) and fast interpretable greedy-tree sums (FIGS) to improve the prediction performance of RFs. In brief, HS mitigates overfitting in the trees by regularizing and shrinking the predictions in a node towards the sample means of its ancestors. FIGS mitigates the inefficiency of tree-based models for additive generative models by growing additive sums of trees.

 

To complement these methodological innovations, the PI also studied random forests (RFs) theoretically, providing new insights into their properties and laying a more rigorous theoretical foundation. In particular, the PI studied feature selection consistency theory for RFs and proved that a simplified version of iRF can discover boolean-type interaction rules under the Locally Spiky Sparse model, a mathematical model inspired by the known thresholding behavior in many biological processes like gene regulation. The PI also proved generalization lower bounds that precisely capture the limitations of classification and regression trees (CART) and other partition-based averaging estimators when fitted to additive generative models. 

 

Beyond random forests, the PI also made contributions to improve both the predictability and interpretability of deep learning methods. This includes research on generating hierarchical interpretations for neural network predictions, attributing importances to features in a transformed space via Transformation Importance (TRIM), and improving the predictive accuracy of deep learning models using existing explanations via contextual decomposition explanation penalization (CDEP) and distilled wavelet-transform information from a trained neural network via adaptive wavelet distillation (AWD).

 

Throughout the duration of this project, the PI developed and expanded upon the principles of modern data science through the predictability, computability, and stability (PCS) framework for veridical (truthful) data science. These principles guided and inspired much of the methodology mentioned previously. The PI is also in the process of writing a textbook entitled Veridical Data Science: The Practice of Responsible Data Analysis and Decision Making to teach reliable Data Science through the lens of the PCS principles and workflow. Furthermore, a python package, VeridicalFlow, was developed to make the practice of veridical data science more broadly accessible.

 

Finally, this project has provided opportunities for many students and postdocs coming from a variety of backgrounds. This included technical research training as well as mentoring. Regarding educational impact, the PI was actively involved with the curriculum development of UC Berkeley?s Data Science Education Program (DSEP) and incorporated a variety of relevant research topics into her course content. Moreover, many of the examples used in her book were motivated by the achievements of this project.
